snippet.title: Descent Maximum (PS1) Gameplay
snippet.description:
This is just a vid of the gameplay in Descent Maximum on the PS1.

I'm playing it on a PS2 with texture smoothing on.

The Descent series was pretty popular for it's time, and still has a good following amongst it's fans. Not so much the PS1 versions, but the PC series.

The Decent games are an interesting mixture of 3D space flight games, and first person shooters. You're enclosed in 3D maze levels, but are in a space craft that controls like it's in a space flight game. You've got 360 degree movement. Down could be up, up could be down, left could be right, and so on depending upon how you go through the levels.

This is the PS1 sequel to the original, and it has added a new guide bot to help you through the giant maze-like levels if you so choose to use it. The original didn't give you the option, so it was easier to get lost. 

This is another one that those who are prone to motion sickness from 3D games should avoid. Especially since it was an early PS1 3D game. Mix in the 360 degree movement with, early 3D visuals, and a framerate dips at times, and I can imagine this game can be quite disorienting at times. I've never gotten motion sickness from a game myself, but I know that a lot of people have.

I haven't played that far into this one yet, because I'm still playing through the original, but this game does allow you to save anywhere on the map, and it even supports Sony's old dual analog flight stick. It doesn't support the dual shock, but if you remember their old dual analog flight stick, it is supported in this game. Even without it, the game still controls very good using the face buttons to move, and the d-pad to aim. Some of the more complex controls, however, require you to hold a button and press another. 

Some gamer will probably be turned off by the simple gameplay of the game. It's the old go get the key to open the door variety, so they may find it to be repetitive. Repetitive, yes, but sometimes you're in the mood for some simple fun. 

You can get both Playstation Descent games for pretty cheap on amazon, or you can get the PC Descent 1&2 for $6 here: 

http://www.gog.com/en/gamecard/descent_1_descent_2

Once again, the PC versions are usually the best versions, but it depends on what kind of gamer you are. I currently own the PS1 versions, but will probably someday go back and buy the PC Descent games. I've still got an old demo of Descent 3 on my computer (from a PC magazine demo from the 1990's). 


NOTE: Perhaps some of you are more prone to remembering Forsaken on the PC, PS1, and N64. It plays similar to Descent, and was obviously inspired by the Descent series. If you're a Forsaken fan, look into Descent, and if you're a Descent fan, look into Forsaken if you haven't already.
